title: Jerry Carl
text:
Jerry Lee Carl Jr. (born June 17, 1958) is an American politician and businessman serving as the <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">U.S. representative</a> for <a href="Alabama%27s%201st%20congressional%20district">Alabama's 1st congressional district</a> since 2021. The district is based in <a href="Mobile%2C%20Alabama">Mobile</a>, and includes most of the state's share of the <a href="Gulf%20Coast">Gulf Coast</a>. A <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a>, Carl served as a member of the <a href="Mobile%20County%2C%20Alabama">Mobile County</a> Commission from 2012 to 2020, the last two years as president of the commission.
In 2019, Carl announced his candidacy for the House seat being vacated by <a href="incumbent">incumbent</a> Republican <a href="Bradley%20Byrne">Bradley Byrne</a>. He defeated former <a href="Alabama%20Senate">State Senator</a> <a href="Bill%20Hightower">Bill Hightower</a> in a runoff for the Republican nomination and <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a> James Averhart in the general election.
Carl is one of <a href="Sedition%20Caucus">147 Republican lawmakers</a> who <a href="Attempts%20to%20overturn%20the%202020%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%23January%206%20joint%20session">voted to overturn results</a> in the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2020 presidential election</a>.
Early life and education.
A native of <a href="Mobile%2C%20Alabama">Mobile, Alabama</a>, Carl graduated from <a href="Sylacauga%20High%20School">Sylacauga High School</a> in 1977. He attended Lake City Community College (now <a href="Florida%20Gateway%20College">Florida Gateway College</a>) for a time, but left to move back to Mobile and start his first business.
Career.
After leaving community college, Carl worked for <a href="Alabama%20Power">Alabama Power</a>. He then worked for Burford Equipment Company and as a salesman for various companies in Mobile. In 1989, Carl established Stat Medical, a healthcare equipment business. He later worked as a manager at Rotech Medical before establishing a real estate development firm. Carl founded Carl and Associates, a management group, in 2003. He then started Cricket and Butterfly, LLC, a lumber and timber company.
Carl ran for Mobile County Commission in 2012. He defeated incumbent <a href="Mike%20Dean%20%28politician%29">Mike Dean</a> in the Republican primary election in April, and won the general election in November. He was reelected over <a href="Margie%20Wilcox">Margie Wilcox</a> in 2016. In 2019, Carl was selected to serve as Commission President.
U.S. House of Representatives.
Elections.
2020.
In June 2020, Carl announced he would run for the 1st district, which was being vacated by seven-term incumbent and fellow Republican <a href="Bradley%20Byrne">Bradley Byrne</a>. He faced former State Senator <a href="Bill%20Hightower">Bill Hightower</a>, <a href="Alabama%20House%20of%20Representatives">State Representative</a> <a href="Chris%20Pringle%20%28politician%29">Chris Pringle</a>, and two others in the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives%20elections%20in%20Alabama%23District%201">Republican primary</a>. Carl narrowly defeated Hightower in the primary, and they went to a runoff election. Carl defeated Democratic nominee James Averhart in the general election with 64.4% of the vote. The 1st has been in Republican hands without interruption since 1965, and the Democrats have only managed 40% of the vote once since then. 
The 1st typically gives its incumbents very long tenures in Washington. When Carl took office on January 2, 2021, he became only the seventh person to hold the seat since 1919; all but one of his six predecessors held it for at least 10 years.
Tenure.
117th Congress (2021–present).
One of Carl's first votes upon joining Congress was opposing the <a href="second%20impeachment%20of%20Donald%20Trump">second impeachment of Donald Trump</a>. He said he voted against impeachment because he believed the <a href="articles%20of%20impeachment">articles of impeachment</a> "failed to reach the necessary threshold for impeachment." He also called impeachment "Nancy Pelosi's personal vendetta against President Trump." Carl voted against the <a href="American%20Rescue%20Plan">American Rescue Plan</a> in March 2021, saying the bill was "rushed" too soon after the passing of the <a href="Consolidated%20Appropriations%20Act%2C%202021">Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021</a> and that it was too big and would add to the increasing <a href="national%20debt">national debt</a>.
As of January 2022, Carl had voted in line with <a href="Joe%20Biden">Joe Biden</a>'s stated position 8% of the time.
Political positions.
Carl is a self-described <a href="Conservatism%20in%20the%20United%20States">conservative</a>.
Abortion.
Carl is anti-abortion, saying in a campaign advertisement that "it’s immoral to stop a beating heart". He has similarly promised to "protect the unborn."
Immigration.
Carl supports the <a href="Trump%20wall">Trump wall</a> on the U.S.–Mexico border, saying, "Jerry will stand with Trump, build the wall and end handouts for lawbreaking illegals."
Gun control.
Carl has said, "As a conservative, he'll stop liberals from destroying the Second Amendment." The <a href="National%20Rifle%20Association">National Rifle Association</a>'s <a href="Political%20Victory%20Fund">Political Victory Fund</a> endorsed him in 2020, claiming that he supports <a href="right%20to%20carry">right to carry</a> legislation.
Impeachment of Donald Trump.
Carl voted against the <a href="second%20impeachment%20of%20Donald%20Trump">second impeachment of Donald Trump</a>, and voted to object to Pennsylvania's and Arizona's electors during the <a href="2021%20United%20States%20Electoral%20College%20vote%20count">2021 United States Electoral College vote count</a>.
Climate change.
Carl opposed President Joe Biden's <a href="Environmental%20policy%20of%20the%20Joe%20Biden%20administration">moratorium on oil and gas production</a>, claiming it would destroy as many as 24,000 jobs in Alabama.
Vote to overturn 2020 election.
On January 6, 2021, Carl was one of <a href="Sedition%20Caucus">147 Republican lawmakers</a> who <a href="Attempts%20to%20overturn%20the%202020%20United%20States%20presidential%20election%23January%206%20joint%20session">voted to overturn results</a> in the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2020 presidential election</a>.
Personal life.
Carl married Tina in 1981, and they have two children.
